repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:

Described in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/35316, there are some inconsistencies within the lua API.
`:h dev-name-common` states that "buf" should be used instead of "buffer"
but there are cases where buffer is mentioned in the lua API.

Solution:

This commit renames occurrences of "buffer" to "buf" for consistency
with the documentation.

comment_data.body: avoid unrelated formatting changes
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -350,7 +350,7 @@ local function add_mark(m, buf, line, next_marks)
   end
 
   local empty = cur_opts.end_line < cur_start_l
-    or (cur_opts.end_line == cur_start_l and cur_opts.end_col <= cur_start_c)
+      or (cur_opts.end_line == cur_start_l and cur_opts.end_col <= cur_start_c)

comment_data.body:
API functions like `nvim_buf_set_keymap` and `nvim_exec_autocmds` will need to support both `buf` and `buffer` (for backwards compatibility).

But all the Lua things that wrap them can just pass `buf` to the API functions; the Lua wrappers don't need to explicitly support both.
These are annotations for the Vim script `sign_*` built-ins, which weren't changed by this PR (and ought not to be).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -196,19 +196,19 @@
 --- @field priority? integer
 
 --- @class vim.fn.sign_placelist.list.item
---- @field buffer integer|string
+--- @field buf integer|string
 --- @field group? string
 --- @field id? integer
 --- @field lnum? integer|string
 --- @field name string
 --- @field priority? integer
 
 --- @class vim.fn.sign_unplace.dict
---- @field buffer? integer|string
+--- @field buf? integer|string
 --- @field id? integer
 
 --- @class vim.fn.sign_unplacelist.list.item
---- @field buffer? integer|string
+--- @field buf? integer|string
 --- @field group? string
 --- @field id? integer

comment_data.body: This is the return value for `nvim_get_autocmds`, which this PR didn't change.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -65,7 +65,7 @@ error('Cannot require a meta file')
 --- @field once? boolean
 --- @field pattern? string
 --- @field buflocal? boolean
---- @field buffer? integer
+--- @field buf? integer

comment_data.body: Same, but `nvim_get_keymap`...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -169,7 +169,7 @@ error('Cannot require a meta file')
 
 --- @class vim.api.keyset.get_keymap
 --- @field abbr? 0|1
---- @field buffer? 0|1
+--- @field buf? 0|1

comment_data.body: IMO keeping the old form documented everywhere is just noise. (Especially as its repeating the same info as `buf`)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1970,7 +1970,10 @@ nvim_clear_autocmds({opts})                            *nvim_clear_autocmds()*
                       `test.py` will not match the pattern.
                   • defaults to clearing all patterns.
                   • NOTE: Cannot be used with {buffer}
-                • buffer: (bufnr)
+                • buf: (bufnr)
+                  • clear only |autocmd-buflocal| autocommands.
+                  • NOTE: Cannot be used with {pattern}
+                • buffer: (bufnr) (deprecatd) use buf.

comment_data.body: Probably should be changed, or maybe in a followup. The old `buffer` field will just be redundantly available.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -65,7 +65,7 @@ error('Cannot require a meta file')
 --- @field once? boolean
 --- @field pattern? string
 --- @field buflocal? boolean
---- @field buffer? integer
+--- @field buf? integer

@@ -9,11 +9,12 @@ local keymap = {}
 --- @inlinedoc
 ---
 --- Creates buffer-local mapping, `0` or `true` for current buffer.
---- @field buffer? integer|boolean
+--- @field buf? integer|boolean
 ---
 --- Make the mapping recursive. Inverse of {noremap}.
 --- (Default: `false`)
 --- @field remap? boolean
+--- @nodoc

comment_data.body:
just set `opts.buffer=nil` immediately after line 74. that makes the rest of the code clearer, it will only deal with `opts.buf`.

same comment if there are similar cases in the rest of the PR
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,13 +71,16 @@ function keymap.set(mode, lhs, rhs, opts)
     rhs = ''
   end
 
-  if opts.buffer then
-    local bufnr = opts.buffer == true and 0 or opts.buffer --[[@as integer]]
+  opts.buf = opts.buffer or opts.buf
+  if opts.buf then
+    local bufnr = opts.buf == true and 0 or opts.buf --[[@as integer]]
+    opts.buf = nil ---@type integer?
     opts.buffer = nil ---@type integer?
     for _, m in ipairs(mode) do
       vim.api.nvim_buf_set_keymap(bufnr, m, lhs, rhs, opts)
     end
   else
+    opts.buf = nil
     opts.buffer = nil

comment_data.body:
instead of adding all these conditions throughout the code, at the top of this function, just do the same approach as you did in Lua, except in C. I.e.,

- If `opts->buf` is provided then ignore `opts->buffer`. 
- If `opts->buffer` is provided (but not `buf`), copy it to `buf`.


sample code: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35330#discussion_r2314481968

This should make the rest of the code much simpler:

```c
Buffer buf = HAS_KEY(opts, get_autocmds, buf)
  ? opts->buf
  : (HAS_KEY(opts, get_autocmds, buffer) ? opts->buffer : 0)
bool has_buf = !!buf;
```

then just use `buf` in the rest of the code, instead of `opts->buf`/`opts->buffer`. hopefully that should work :)
yeah, like this. nit: use ternary

```suggestion
  Buffer buffer;  // deprecated, use "buf"
```

same for other cases below
ternary

I think buf should probably take precedence
```suggestion
  opts.buf = opts.buf or opts.buffer
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,14 +70,16 @@ function keymap.set(mode, lhs, rhs, opts)
     rhs = ''
   end
 
-  if opts.buffer then
-    local bufnr = opts.buffer == true and 0 or opts.buffer --[[@as integer]]
-    opts.buffer = nil ---@type integer?
+  opts.buf = opts.buffer or opts.buf

comment_data.body: what is the intention of this code?
Unmarking as resolved; `buffer` is still being documented.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1970,7 +1970,10 @@ nvim_clear_autocmds({opts})                            *nvim_clear_autocmds()*
                       `test.py` will not match the pattern.
                   • defaults to clearing all patterns.
                   • NOTE: Cannot be used with {buffer}
-                • buffer: (bufnr)
+                • buf: (bufnr)
+                  • clear only |autocmd-buflocal| autocommands.
+                  • NOTE: Cannot be used with {pattern}
+                • buffer: (bufnr) (deprecatd) use buf.

comment_data.body: I'd imagine not, but is it wanted for these changes to apply to Vim's `sign_*` built-ins too like here? @justinmk
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -196,19 +196,19 @@
 --- @field priority? integer
 
 --- @class vim.fn.sign_placelist.list.item
---- @field buffer integer|string
+--- @field buf integer|string
 --- @field group? string
 --- @field id? integer
 --- @field lnum? integer|string
 --- @field name string
 --- @field priority? integer
 
 --- @class vim.fn.sign_unplace.dict
---- @field buffer? integer|string
+--- @field buf? integer|string
 --- @field id? integer

---- @field buffer? integer|string
+--- @field buf? integer|string
 --- @field group? string
 --- @field id? integer

comment_data.body:
`buf` shouldn't be `bool`, but also using 0 as the sentinel is wrong (it means the current buffer).

For example, setting `buf = 0` no longer just clears the buffer-local autocommands, but clears all of them.
Relying on a different sentinel would just mean a user could pass that sentinel as `buf` and have it act like no `buf` was provided. (This implementation detail shouldn't leak)

It's probably more correct to have `has_buf` be `HAS_KEY(..., buffer) || HAS_KEY(..., buf)` and make _very_ sure `buf` is not used in paths where that is false. Also, maybe it should be an error if both `buf` and `buffer` are specified? @justinmk (Currently `buffer` will have priority)

(Also FYI there's currently failing tests)
Same probably also applies here, but this one has the right type. (Though maybe it'd be better as `Buffer`?)

```suggestion
           "%s", "Cannot use both 'pattern' and 'buf'", {
```

Maybe best if these errors refer to `buf` now; dunno if there's others.

comment_regular_data.body: This looks pretty good. Having to type out "buffer" always feels super lame.
Sorry if I'm wrong, but looks like this PR only just replace `opts.buffer` with `opts.buf`, without deprecation phase for the first one?

> but looks like this PR only just replace `opts.buffer` with `opts.buf`, without deprecation phase for the first one?

the Lua layer may need something like `opts.buf = opts.buffer or opts.buf` but otherwise just [passthrough to API](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35330#discussion_r2296770134), generally.

> the Lua layer may need something like opts.buf = opts.buffer or opts.buf

Yes, I think this way is good enough

@justinmk Still finding my feet in contributing to the project so please forgive me, but have a few questions:

How would I go about changing `buffer` to `buf` in the generated files, such as `neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_meta/api.lua`? My first thought here is this is generated from the C matching functions but changing them and rebuilding didn't seem to change these generated files (or I might be missing something)?

Also just unsure on the specifics of supporting both `buffer` and `buf`. So functionality we have that isn't a direct API call can be left alone (because we'll handle the `buffer -> buf` at the lowest level), unless it uses the `buffer` reference specifically? But the lowest API will need to look for both `buffer` and `buf`? If that's the case, this kinda comes back to the first question of not really understanding where those lowest lua API's are generated from. 

Apologies if this doesn't make complete sense, trying to learn how this all works 😄

> How would I go about changing `buffer` to `buf` in the generated files, such as `neovim/runtime/lua/vim/_meta/api.lua`? 

Change the `@param` in the docstrings, then run `make doc`.



> unsure on the specifics of supporting both `buffer` and `buf`

Change the logic in a way that doesn't break backwards-compatibility :)

Making this ready for review - think it's getting to a good state:

- ~Unsure on the uncrustify lint.~ Got it
- Probably missing some deprecation docs but need some guidance on where to put this.
- I've marked functions with `buffer` being deprecated - `buffer [description of param] (deprecated) use buf` - unsure if this is how parameters are deprecated.

labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(lua): rename buffer to buf
